Key Arguments: The legislation will severely restrict freedom of speech and lead to unintended consequences.
The government is exempt from the legislation, which is problematic as governments can be wrong or deceptive.
The legislation could be used politically to restrict electoral communications.
There is a contradiction regarding the exemption of private messages, leading to potential monitoring and censorship.
Fact-checkers and third-party contractors may introduce political bias.
The legislation abrogates the right against self-incrimination, which is a dangerous legal precedent.
The fines and penalties are excessive and will deter free speech beyond the intended scope of the legislation.
Historical examples show that questioning established beliefs is crucial for progress, and the legislation could stifle such questioning.
Notable Quotes: We have achieved the current level of civilisation because of constant questioning and adherence to the scientific method.
It cannot be assumed that government is always benign or correct.
The best way to refute mis- and disinformation is to allow debate, and to explain the government beliefs and the facts and logic behind that belief.
